The '''Venus Throw''' was the highest roll in the [[Ancient Rome|Ancient Roman]] gambling game of ''tali'' ([[knucklebones]]). The game was played with four 4-sided rectangular dice numbered I, III, IV and VI, usually made from sheep's or goat's knucklebones. In a Venus Throw, each ''talus'' landed on a different side, yielding as a score of 14. A gambler would either throw the ''tali'' from his or her hand, or from a small box, (called a ''fritillus''). Thirty-five different throws were possible. While the Venus throw was the highest, the Vulture throw (all aces) — also known as the Dog throw — was the lowest. The Venus throw could be used to designate the master of the revels.
''The Venus Throw'' is also a novel in the [[Roma Sub Rosa]] series set in ancient republican Rome by author [[Steven Saylor]].
==References== * Smith, Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities, p. 1095 [http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-dgra/1102.html] * Charlton T. Lewis; Charles Short A Latin Dictionary, p. 782 [[Category:Ancient Roman culture]] [[Category:Gambling terminology]]

{{BLP sources|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Willa Ford | background = solo_singer | image = Willa Ford and Mike Modano.jpg | image_size = | caption = Ford (left) with [[Mike Modano]] (right) | birth_name = Amanda Lee Williford | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1981|01|22}} | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Dance-pop|Dance]] | occupation = [[Singer]], [[songwriter]], [[dancer]], [[record producer]], [[Television presenter|presenter]], [[actress]] | years_active = 1999–present | label = [[Music Corporation of America|MCA]] (1999–2000)
[[Lava Records|Lava]]/[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]] (2000–2004) | associated_acts = [['N Sync]] | website = http://www.willa-ford.org/ }} '''Amanda Lee Williford''' (born January 22, 1981),{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/music/artist/ford_willa/artist.jhtml|title=Willa Ford|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=August 7, 2012}} known by her [[stage name]] '''Willa Ford''', is an [[United States|American]] [[singer]], [[songwriter]], [[dancer]], [[Model (person)|model]], [[television personality]] and [[film actress]]. She released her debut album, ''[[Willa Was Here]]'', in 2001. Ford also has appeared in movies such as ''[[Friday the 13th (2009 film)|Friday the 13th]]'' (2009), hosted several [[reality television]] shows, posed for ''[[Playboy]]'' and competed on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Dancing with the Stars (US TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]''. ==Early life and education== Ford was raised in [[Ruskin, Florida]]. She began singing with the Tampa Bay Children's Choir at age eight. At age 11, she started singing with the Tampa-based children's performing arts troupe, Entertainment Revue. She attended [[East Bay High School]] in [[Gibsonton, Florida]]. ==Career== ===Music career=== In 1999, the 18-year-old Ford started performing under the stage name Mandah and was signed to [[Music Corporation of America|MCA]]. Ford was later dropped from MCA and signed by [[Atlantic Records]]. Atlantic placed one of Ford's songs, "Lullaby," on the soundtrack for ''[[Pokémon: The First Movie]]''. Ford changed her stage name from Mandah to Willa Ford in order to avoid confusion with [[Mandy Moore]]. In 2000, she was one of the opening acts on the [[Backstreet Boys]]' "Into the Millennium" tour. In 2001, Ford signed on to a new label, Lava [[Atlantic Records]], while on a [[Shopping mall|mall tour]] for [[Nautica (clothing company)|Nautica Kids]]. Ford wrote most of her own lyrics and served as executive [[Record producer|producer]] for most of her first album. On July 17, 2001, she released ''[[Willa Was Here]]''. The album included the single "[[I Wanna Be Bad]]" which featured rapper [[Royce da 5'9"]]. ''Willa Was Here'' reached 56 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and sold approximately 200,000 copies.{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}} Ford went on to release a second single from the album, "[[Did Ya' Understand That]]," which failed to garner much attention. Later she explained the reason as the song was released on September 11, 2001 and ruined by the terrorists' attack.{{cite web |publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7880907/willa-ford-i-wanna-be-bad-interview |title=Willa Ford Explains Why She Left Music -- And Teases a Possible Comeback |author= Kaplan, Ilana |date=July 25, 2017 |accessdate=September 2, 2017}} "Ooh Ooh" was released as a promotional single, but also failed to find success. Ford was a spokesperson for [[Pantene]] Pro-V's ProVoice campaign while promoting the album. She also appeared in [[Uncle Kracker]]'s [[Music video|video]] for "In A Little While." Ford also went on to guest-host [[MTV]]'s ''[[Total Request Live|TRL]]'' and ''Say What Karaoke'', which led to a hosting contract with [[Viacom]]. Ford hosted the MTV reality shows ''The Morning After'' and ''[[I Bet You Will]]''. In 2001, Ford also co-wrote and recorded a duet with South Korean pop star [[Park Ji-yoon]]. The song, titled "Nastified," appeared on Park's fifth album, ''Man.'' In 2003, Ford released a song titled "[[A Toast to Men]]." The song, which featured guest rapper [[Lady May]], was featured in daytime promotional ads for soap operas. The single came from her unreleased second album ''Sexysexobsessive'', which was previously titled ''Porn Poetry''. The title track, "Sexysexobsessive," was to be the second single, but it was only released through Ford's official website. From 2005 to 2006, she appeared as a guest doll in [[Pussycat Dolls]]' show at the club in [[Las Vegas]]. In 2010, she released the first song since 2003 "All This Time" online, collaborated with [[Riley Smith]]. In 2011, Ford resumed her music career with a performance at [[The Viper Room]] in [[Los Angeles|LA]]. In the performance, she revealed her first solo song since 2003, "Back Back Back." In 2014, she was featured in the song "Rock Tonight" by Willa Ford, Eve Nelson and Ray Cervenka.{{cite web|url=http://soundcloud.com/raycervenka/rock-tonight-willa-ford|title=Rock Tonight- Willa Ford|website=Soundcloud.com|accessdate=9 June 2018}} ===Television, film, and magazine appearances=== In 2002, Ford appeared in an episode of the short-lived [[television]] sitcom ''[[Raising Dad]],'' playing a [[Bullying|bully]] named Edie. In 2005, Ford hosted the first season of the reality show ''[[The Ultimate Fighter]]'' on [[Spike TV]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/willa-ford/bio/213554|title=Willa Ford: Biography|publisher=[[TVGuide]]|accessdate=August 7, 2012}} After the show's finale, Ford was contracted as a summer's guest doll performer for the [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]] shows of [[The Pussycat Dolls]]. Ford was later featured as the June celebrity on ''[[FHM]]'''s 2005 [[Pin-up girl|pin-up calendar]]. In early 2006, Ford played as one of the four [[Quarterback|celebrity quarterbacks]] for the [[Legends Cup (LFL)|Lingerie Bowl]], which was shown during the half-time of [[Super Bowl XL]]. Later that year, she was featured in a [[Model (art)|nude pictorial]] in the March 2006 issue of ''[[Playboy]]''. ''Stuff'' magazine ranked her #48 in the 101 Sexiest Online Women supplement later that year. In fall 2006, Ford competed on the third season of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 3)|Dancing with the Stars]]''. Ford and her partner, [[Maksim Chmerkovskiy]], were eliminated in the fifth week of competition. She talked about her experience with ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'' in its January 2007 issue. Ford appeared on an episode of ''My Celebrity Home'' on the [[Style Network]], which aired on January 31, 2007 {{cite web | url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/my-celebrity-home-2007/episode-7-season-2/willa-ford/433168 | title=Episode Detail: Willa Ford - My Celebrity Home | work=TV Guide | accessdate=2013-05-25}} She also hosted the third season of ''[[Pants-Off Dance-Off]]'' on [[Fuse TV]]. On August 23, 2007, Ford and her then-husband, [[National Hockey League|NHL]] hockey player [[Mike Modano]], were featured in an episode of ''[[MTV Cribs]]''. Ford appeared in the 2009 [[slasher film]] ''[[Friday the 13th (2009 film)|Friday the 13th]]''. To promote the project, Ford appeared as a guest on [[E!]]'s late night talk show ''[[Chelsea Lately]]'' on February 5, 2009.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} On October 10, 2009, she was cast as Becca in [[Dreamfly Production]]'s new movie, ''[[Universal Squadrons]],'' which was originally titled ''Minuteman''.{{cite web | url=http://www.minutemanthemovie.com/site/news.html | title=News | work=Minuteman | accessdate=2013-05-25 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The movie premiered at the [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]] International Independent Film Festival 2010{{cite web|title=Dreamfly Productions|url=http://www.dreamflyproductions.com/|accessdate=25 May 2013}} and the Angelika Theater in [[Dallas, Texas]] in December. According to the blog of the production, the movie was released for [[pay per view]]/[[video on demand]] in April, then [[DVD]] in June 7, 2011 from Maverick Films.{{cite web | url=http://www.maverickentertainment.cc/titles5.php | title=All Titles | work=Maverick Entertainment | accessdate=2013-05-25}} Ford also made a guest appearance in one episode of ''[[The Glades (TV series)|The Glades]]'' in 2011. In 2012, she appeared in 4 episodes of the television program ''[[Magic City (TV series)|Magic City]]'' and an episode of ''[[Leverage (TV series)|Leverage]]'' season five. As of June 2014, she is taking part in 4 films, called ''Submerged'',{{cite web|url=http://www.thehollywoodnews.com/2013/10/03/steven-c-miller-direct-submerged/|title=Steven C. Miller To Direct 'Submerged'|first=Luke Ryan|last=Baldock|date=3 October 2013|website=Thehollywoodnews.com|accessdate=9 June 2018}} ''Any Day'', ''The Nurse'', and ''Checkmate''.{{cite web|url=http://www.statusmedia-ent.com/#!film-production-news/c21i3|title=status-media|website=Statusmedia-ent.com|accessdate=9 June 2018}} Ford was also cast in another movie, ''Assassin's Fury'', but was later dropped. In an interview with BZFilm.com, producer Fabio Soldani said that Ford was replaced after five days of shooting and that Willa was "a nightmare to be around" and "shooting was a really sad place to be for those 5 days".{{cite web | url=http://bzfilm.com/talks-interviews/real-nightmare-on-set-of-independent-action-film-exclusive/ | title=Real nightmare on set of independent action film | work= BZFilm.com | accessdate=2014-04-25}} ==Personal life== Ford and hockey player [[Mike Modano]] married in a small, private ceremony on August 25, 2007, in [[Athens, Texas]].{{cite web | url=http://www.eonline.com/news/56017/willa-ford-weds-hockey-beau | title=Willa Ford Weds Hockey Beau | work=E! | date=27 August 2007 | accessdate=2013-05-25 | author=Hall, Sarah}}{{cite news | title=Willa you? We do! CELEBRITY EVENT: Stars' Modano, actress-singer Ford wed in East Texas | work=The Dallas Morning News | date=26 August 2007 | author=Peppard, Alan}} In August 2012, Ford and Modano announced that they were divorcing.{{cite web |publisher=[[People (magazine)|People]] |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20618741,00.html |title=Willa Ford and Husband to Divorce |date=August 7, 2012 |accessdate=August 7, 2012}} In April 2015, Ford married former [[NFL]] linebacker [[Ryan Nece]].Vanier, Jayme (October 8, 2015) {{cite web|url=http://agoodaffair.com/willa-ford-and-ryan-nece-luxury-orange-county-wedding/|title=Willa Ford and Ryan Nece's Orange County Wedding}}. ''Agoodaffair.com''. Retrieved June 18, 2016. In March 2016, it was announced that the couple was expecting their first child.{{Cite web|title=Willa Ford Is Pregnant, Expecting First Child With Husband Ryan Nece|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/749521/willa-ford-is-pregnant-expecting-first-child-with-husband-ryan-nece|website=E!Online|author=Bacardi, Francesca|date=2016-03-18|accessdate=2016-03-31}} On September 7, 2016, Ford gave birth to a son.{{cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2016/09/12/willa-ford-ryan-nece-welcome-son/|title=Willa Ford and Ryan Nece Welcome a Son|website=Celebritybabies.people.com|accessdate=9 June 2018}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+ List of studio albums, with selected chart positions, sales, and certifications ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:5em;"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:17em;"| Album details ! scope="col" colspan="1"| Peaks |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:85%;"| [[Billboard 200|US]]

Chris Drew | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = [[English language|English]] | num_seasons = 7 | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = [[Alex Shane]] | producer = | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = | company = Tri-Vision Media | distributor = | channel = [[Challenge (TV channel)|Challenge]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = {{Start date|df=yes|2012|08|26}} | last_aired = {{End date|df=yes|2015|12|27}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related =[[BWC: British Wrestling Round-Up]] | website =http://www.wrestletalk.tv | website_title =Official website | production_website = }} '''''Wrestle Talk TV''''' is a weekly (originally fortnightly) [[talk show]] about [[professional wrestling]]. It is presented by Francesca Wood and Adam Brown (who replaced [[Marty Scurll]]). It was first hosted by [[Joel Ross]], and then by various guest hosts for a period in 2014. The show was released monthly on [[YouTube]] from September 2011 to March 2012, before it moved to the television channel [[Challenge (TV channel)|Challenge]] in the [[United Kingdom]], on August 2012. Wrestle Talk TV is now an official daily wrestling YouTube show hosted by Oli Davis, Luke Owen and Laurie Blake. They also have a podcast WrestleRamble. ==WrestleRamble== Wrestle Talks YouTube channel started the WrestleRamble, known then as ThatWrestleTalkShow, in April 2017. It is hosted by Oli Davis, Luke Owen and occasionally Laurie Blake. On the podcast they review WWE Raw, SmackDown and PPV. Occasionally they review NJPW shows. They have also reviewed All In. == Episodes == === YouTube series === *Aired from 26 September 2011 to 27 March 2012 === Season 1 === *Aired from 26 August 2012 to 24 February 2013 === Season 2 === *Aired from 3 March 2013 to 1 September 2013 === Season 3 === *Aired from 8 September 2013 to 29 December 2013 === Season 4 === *Aired from 9 February 2014 to 21 September 2014 === Season 5 === *Aired from 5 October 2014 to 28 December 2014 === Season 6 === *Aired from 4 January 2015 to 12 July 2015 === Season 7 === *Aired from 19 July 2015 to 27 December 2015 ==See also== {{Portal|Professional wrestling|United Kingdom}} *[[TNA British Boot Camp]] *[[List of professional wrestling television series]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== [[Category:Professional wrestling television series]] [[Category:YouTube series]] [[Category:2010s British television series]] [[Category:2011 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2015 British television programme endings]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Professional wrestling in the United Kingdom]] {{talk-tv-prog-stub}} {{Wrestling-stub}} https://m.youtube.com/user/WrestletalkTV

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Yolanda Mero | image = Normal 36748-Yolanda-Mero.jpeg | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | native_name = Mérő Yolanda | native_name_lang = hu | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1887|08|30}} | birth_place = [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1963|10|17|1887|08|30}} | death_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | genre = [[Classical music|classical]] | occupation = Classical pianist | instrument = [[Piano]] | years_active = 1902–1963 | label = | associated_acts = }} '''Yolanda Mero''' (aka Jolanda Mero;<ref>[http://www.classicalmusicguide.com/viewtopic.php?f=10&t=24883&start=0 Classical Music Guide Forums]</ref> Hungarian spelling '''Mérő'''; later '''Mero-Irion''') (30 August 1887{{spaced ndash}}17 October 1963)<ref name=women/> was a [[Hungarian-American]] pianist, opera and theatre impresario, and philanthropist who supported destitute musicians.
==Pianist== Yolanda Mero was born into a [[Hungarian Jews|Jewish family]] in [[Budapest]] to Salamon Mérő and Rozalia (née Pick).<ref name=women>[http://www.pianowomen.com/yesterday.html Women at the Piano]</ref> She began studying at the age of 8 at the National Conservatory with Augusta Rennebaum, a pupil of [[Franz Liszt]].<ref name=CO>[http://www.classicsonline.com/catalogue/product.aspx?pid=484 Classics Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708163224/http://www.classicsonline.com/catalogue/product.aspx?pid=484 |date=July 8, 2011 }}</ref> She made her debut at age 15 with the [[Dresden Philharmonic]], then toured the world for four years.<ref name=auto>[http://www.rgrossmusicautograph.com/instrumental75.html rgross.musicautograph.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724191958/http://www.rgrossmusicautograph.com/instrumental75.html |date=July 24, 2011 }}</ref> She moved to the [[United States]] in 1900, first appearing in New York in 1909, with the Russian Symphony Orchestra.<ref name=time/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lXag39roRosC&pg=PA182 Susana Salgado, The Teatro Solis: 150 Years of Opera, Concert and Ballet in Montevideo]</ref>
A week after arriving in New York, she met Hermann Irion, an executive of the Steinway Piano company, and married him only four weeks later, on 16 December 1909.<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1909/12/17/101909032.pdf New York Times, 17 December 1909]</ref><ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1909/12/17/101909111.pdf New York Times, 17 December 1909]</ref>
In the US she played concertos under the baton of [[Gustav Mahler]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=kB6vuf0aGOgC&pg=PA310 Gustav Mahler’s American Years, 1907-1911]</ref> [[Leopold Stokowski]]<ref>[http://www.classical.net/music/guide/society/lssa/concertregister.php Classical Net]</ref> and others. She later had a teaching post at her alma mater in Budapest.<ref name=CO/>
Her verve and bravura, but also her wayward approach, were noted. In a review of her concert at New York's Aeolian Hall in January 1919, [[James Huneker]] wrote that "... she transformed Chopin preludes into veritable typhoons", and "... in the [[Barcarole (Chopin)|Barcarolle]], instead of gondolas and the vows of lovers, moonlight and soft Adriatic zephyrs, we were shown a huge warship that steamed through the Grand Canal, sirens screaming, cannons booming, and a band playing Hungarian Rhapsody by Liszt."<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1919/01/14/109331138.pdf New York Times, 14 January 1919]</ref>
==Recordings== Yolanda Mero made a number of piano rolls, of music by [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]], [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]], [[Sergei Bortkiewicz]], [[Cécile Chaminade]], [[Claude Debussy|Debussy]], [[Ernő Dohnányi|Dohnányi]], [[Edvard Grieg|Grieg]], [[George Frideric Handel|Handel]], [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]], [[Franz Liszt|Liszt]], [[Moritz Moszkowski|Moszkowski]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Anton Rubinstein]], [[Franz Schubert|Schubert]], [[Christian Sinding|Sinding]], [[Johann Strauss II]], [[Richard Strauss]], [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]], [[Max Vogrich]] and [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]].<ref>[http://www.rprf.org/PDF/Piano_Roll_Catalog.pdf Piano Roll Transfer Catalog] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723203816/http://www.rprf.org/PDF/Piano_Roll_Catalog.pdf |date=July 23, 2011 }}</ref> She made only one 78rpm recording.<ref name=CO/>
Sergei Bortkiewicz dedicated his ''Trois pièces pour piano'', Op. 12, to her.<ref>[http://www.pianopedia.com/w_6472_bortkiewicz.aspx Pianopedia]</ref>
Her recording of Max Vogrich's ''Staccato-Caprice'' appears on the CD ''Women at the Piano: An Anthology of Historic Performances, Vol. 2'' (1926-1950).<ref>[http://www.classicsonline.com/catalogue/product.aspx?pid=484# Classics Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708163224/http://www.classicsonline.com/catalogue/product.aspx?pid=484# |date=July 8, 2011 }}</ref> and on Welte-Mignon Piano Rolls, Vol. 1 (1905-1927)<ref>[http://www.classicsonline.com/catalogue/product.aspx?pid=245# Classics Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708163232/http://www.classicsonline.com/catalogue/product.aspx?pid=245# |date=July 8, 2011 }}</ref> It is said to display her "superb finish, beautiful phrasing and exquisite touch".<ref name=CO/> Her recording of [[Carl Heymann]]'s ''Elfenspiel, Etude in E major'' appears on Welte-Mignon Piano Rolls, Vol. 3 (1905-1926).<ref>[http://www.classicsonline.com/catalogue/product.aspx?pid=247 Classics Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708163241/http://www.classicsonline.com/catalogue/product.aspx?pid=247 |date=July 8, 2011 }}</ref> Her playing of [[Franz Liszt]]'s [[Hungarian Rhapsodies|Hungarian Rhapsody No. 4]] is on {{YouTube|yaaVvnNtt6I|this video}}, and can also be found on CD.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Multitude of Pianists - Various Artists|url=http://www.lib.umd.edu/ipam/recordings-and-publications/anderson-disc|publisher=[[International Piano Archives|International Piano Archives at Maryland]]|accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref>
==Impresario== Mme Mero-Irion co-founded the New Opera Company, becoming at that time the world's only female [[impresario]]. She chose the repertoire, singers, conductors, artistic and stage directors, ballet masters and coaches.<ref name=time>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,932881,00.html Time, 16 November 1942]</ref><ref>[http://www.historyforsale.com/html/prodetails.asp?bw=1&documentid=19293 History for Sale]</ref> She produced ''[[The Merry Widow]]'' on Broadway in 1943, with choreography by [[George Balanchine]] and starring [[Jan Kiepura]], [[David Wayne]], [[Robert Rounseville]] and others, and [[Marcel Pagnol]]'s play ''[[Topaze (play)|Topaze]]'', starring [[Tilly Losch]], in 1947.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZWIRAljCR7oC&pg=PA284 Stanley Green, Encyclopedia of the Musical Theatre]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=7o_3HtDDCAgC&pg=PA198 George John Nathan, Theatre Book of the Year 1947-48]</ref>
==Radio activist== She also became an activist in the cause of improving the quality of the content of radio broadcasts, launching attacks on soap operas and advertising.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=LzgaoIIkwKEC&pg=PA139 Kathy M Newman, Radio active: advertising and consumer activism, 1935-47]</ref> She was founder and chairman of the Women's National Radio Committee and created the Gold Microphone Award.<ref>[http://www.liveauctioneers.com/item/7968844 Live Auctioneers]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=7xkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT6 Billboard, 18 May 1946]</ref>
==Philanthropist== Yolanda Mero-Irion was active in providing support for destitute musicians. She co-founded the Musicians Emergency Fund, along with [[Olga Samaroff]], [[Lucrezia Bori]] and the wives of [[Ernest Schelling]] and [[Ernest Hutcheson]]<ref name=auto/> and was its executive director.<ref>[https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1961/04/15/fund-founder The New Yorker, 15 April 1961]</ref> She established an endowment with the Musicians Foundation, Inc.<ref>[http://www.musiciansfoundation.org/ Musicians Foundation, Inc.]</ref>
Yolanda Mero-Irion lived with her husband on their estate in Rockland County, NY.<ref name=time/> She later lived at 983 Park Avenue, New York. She died on 17 October 1963, in Lenox Hill Hospital, aged 76.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1963/10/19/archives/mrs-yolanda-meroirion-dead-organized-musicians-aid-fund-gave-up.html New York Times, abstract]</ref>
